div1.p:
An apology is in order for not letting you know sooner that the Chicago trip had been made much sooner than we had planned. It was this way: When I arrived at my home in Lockwood, I found my sister-in-law in the middle of her plans to visit her family in southern Wisconsin. Just like that she asked me to go along— and since it isn't hard to push me into packing my toothbrush, I went along. Then I realized there would be a stop in Chicago, so.— then I was calling the offices of Dr. Snanely and Dr. Beatty on my return. The latter was gone and in his place I tlaked with a Mr. Danielson. He was very cordial but explained immediately that no more or promise could be made pending possible legislative action on the budget slash. He asked that I
later in July and he hoped a good answer could be given. Otherwise, if the slash was carried through, schools would be closed and those teachers transposed. — With Dr. Snanely I had an almost immediate interview on his office — He said— "Come right out"! I did—and I talked for Betty and the possibilities in her field. When Dr. Snavely heard I had just seen you people — I almost had to draw detailed pictures of all of you— He introduced me to two of his nurses although their names didn't stay with me. One was dark haired with a quick concise manners of speaking;- The other, quite heavy — with lighter complexion and a little friendlier attitude— Dr. Snavely took me down to Mrs. Frost's office- and I feel so glad and yet so humble when she heard I knew the Neihardt's. In my conversation with Dr. Snavely, I also asked him what opportuntiies there were for medical social work and he became interested in what my background was then. Boy, it was

fun talking and intended by his offering me a chance to help set up a social work unit for rehabilitating the Indian children in one of the hospitals! I was nearly floored. It all depends on Washington's humor and attitude. So, dear people, that is why it looks as if I "jumped the gun", but I feel I couldn't pass up the opportunity of going in when I had a whole day in Chicago. It still appears that Betty + I will go up in August and we both are to go back for further discussions- Honestly, that is all we've really been discussing — even though we realize Betty's parents will not like the idea at once— They have always envisioned their last and yougnest girl in the nurse's white and surrounded by doctors- etc— but Betty can do a good job of selling ideas to her people — so by the time she finishes the U.S. Public Health Course — the Savers will be "ready" too. She has written to Univ. Minnesota for bulletins.

With this great idea before me, I didn't want to tie myself down too closely on a job, so I did something totally out of my experience. I've signed up to sell World Book Encyclopedias!! Maybe I'm sticking my neck out, but after today's first session on selling tactics, I think it will prove very interesting. It will bring me adequate income and still allow me much personal time and freedom.—
Alice, dear— how much are the pictures- It was so thoughful of you to send them to us. Not all of our rolls are developed yet but if we have any good ones — will send them.
You know, I didn't realize it until it was too late, but my train from Chicago to Janesville, Wisconsin, stopped for a few minutes at Gray's lab— I fairly jumped when I saw the name!!̬

Mr. Neihardt, I wish there was a better way to say thank-you for yoru interest and good wishes and especially for your letters to Chicago. If and when these plans materialize I know they will be due to a large degree to your backing. JOHN G. NEIHARDT CENTER Seeing you dear people again was the "life I needed— the reassurance that ideals and dreams

I hope Dawn finds her sitation in Springfield not too disagreeable. It won't last too long.

closer.salute: With love to all of you—
